title: SCMA General Meeting
description:
Virgil Shields, a longtime SCMA member, will give a historic slide show of his climbs in the 1980’s of the “Celestial Routes” on Temple Crag.  Temple Crag is a peak located in the beautifully spectacular high Sierra and features some long classic lines such as Venusian Blind, Moon Goddess, and Sun Ribbon Arête.

The meeting will be held at the auditorium of the Griffith Park Ranger Headquarters in Griffith Park, 4730 Crystal Springs Drive, Los Angeles.  The meeting begins at 7:30 PM, with the presentation after some brief general club business.  There is no cost to attend and members as well as non-members are always welcome to come and see what the SCMA is all about.
address: 4730 Crystal Springs Drive, Los Angeles, CA 90027, USA

title: Church Dome [G]
description:
Trip leader: Greg Vernon, Michael Gordon

If you enjoy the atmosphere and steep climbing of Holcomb Valley Pinnacles (San Bernardino Mtns), you will love Church Dome!

Travel instructions and other good beta can be found on the Mountain Project site, although MP mis-characterizes CD as "well-bolted sport climbs". You will not do much climbing if you only show up with quickdraws! A full rack is highly recommended.
http://mountainproject.com/v/church-domes/105874984

Church Dome is best for leaders who are comfortable leading 5.8+ (most climbs need to be led first in order to TR), but everyone is welcome.

This is a beautiful time of year in a beautiful Southern Sierra setting, and our campsite is great with a running creek nearby.
address: Forest Route 24S13, Sequoia National Forest, CA, USA

title: CANCELED - Joshua Tree - Braille Trip [G]
description:
This event has unfortunately been cancelled for this year. 

SCMA still has family site reservation at Indian Cove campground. The site # are 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7.  They were reserved from 10/15 to 10/20.  Please feel free to use them if Indian Cove is open this weekend.  Also the SCMA has Group Site #2 in Sheep Pass.

Trip Leader: Mike Jelf.
Indian Cove (Some sites available from the evening of the 15th-20th)

For as long as the SCMA had been an organization, the club has been hosting a weekend of climbing for sight impaired kids and teenagers from the Braille Institute.  October 19-20 will be the 28th time the SCMA provided an opportunity to climb for these kids.  To make the event a success for the few dozen kids that travel from all over Southern California to climb, SCMA volunteers are needed for Saturday and Sunday October 19-20 in Joshua Tree/Indian Cove.

Volunteers are needed in the mornings to set up top-ropes, and then for belaying the kids.   In addition to the SCMA site at Sheep Pass, there will be camping available for volunteers at Indian Cove.  For more information and Indian Cove Campsite information, contact Trip Leader Mike Jelf at m.jelf@netzero.com or (310) 326-3430.

Help make this annual event a success for the SCMA and a special day for the kids.  For just a few hours of volunteer time, you will drive home feeling amazing.
address: Joshua Tree National Park, 74485 National Park Drive, Twentynine Palms, CA 92277, USA

title: Big Rock [G]
description:
Sunday, October 27, Annual Big Rock Potluck Picnic

This is a regular club trip.  All SCMA climbers invited. 

It is on Sunday October 27, not Saturday as was indicated before.

This is a potluck as has been traditional in the past. Please bring a potluck dish if you can. It does not need to be a lot of food.

It will be a fun day of climbing close to picnic tables there.

Water, apple juice, plates, cups, plastic utensils, napkins, paper towels, trash bags, sugary sweets, ice will be brought for everybody.

title: SCMA General Meeting
description:
Don’t miss Miguel Forjan’s presentation of photos and stories from his prolific Sierra soloing season.  Miguel’s free solo ascents this summer include:

Lone Pine Peak, North Ridge
Mt. Whitney, East Buttress
Crystal Crag, North arête
Tenaya Peak,  Northwest Buttress of
Cathedral Peak, Southeast Buttress
Eichorn Peak, North Face
Matthes Crest
Mt. Sill, Swiss Arête
Bear Creek Spire, Northeast Ridge

The meeting will be held at the auditorium of the Griffith Park Ranger Headquarters in Griffith Park, 4730 Crystal Springs Drive, Los Angeles.  The meeting begins at 7:30 PM, with the presentation after some brief general club business.  There is no cost to attend and members as well as non-members are always welcome.
address: 4730 Crystal Springs Drive, Los Angeles, CA 90027, USA

title: Safety Evaluation
description:
The SCMA Safety Committee will be administering the next Safety Evaluation for prospective new members.

Take part in our half-day safety evaluation to demonstrate your proficiency in some basic climbing skills:

  • Tying the basic climbing knots
  • Rappelling
  • Ascending a rope over an overhang using friction knots
  • Setting multi-directional gear anchors
  • Tying off a fallen climber
  • Escape a fallen climber belay
Questions?
address: Joshua Tree National Park, 74485 National Park Drive, Twentynine Palms, CA 92277, USA

Directions to Big Rock.
215 South from the 10 or 60 frwy.
Exit Ramona Expressway. Continue on Ramona passing around the backside of the dam.
Turn Left at Burnasconi Road towards entrance.
Pay for parking using the envelopes. Park and hike the road into the park to Big Rock

RMs and AMs come on out and volunteer.  The success of the class depends on you.   The SCMA will have a potluck and group campsite Saturday night.  Stay over and climb at Big Rock on Sunday.

This will be the fifth and final class for the 2014 Rock Climbing Safety Course.  Student will be tested on the fallen climber tie-off and learn about multi-pitch climbing.
address: Bernasconi Road, Perris, CA 92571, USA
venue: Big Rock, Lake Perris State Recreation Area

title: Safety Evaluation
description:
The SCMA Safety Committee will be administering the next Safety Evaluation for prospective new members.

Take part in our half-day safety evaluation to demonstrate your proficiency in some basic climbing skills:

  • Tying the basic climbing knots
  • Rappelling
  • Ascending a rope over an overhang using friction knots
  • Setting multi-directional gear anchors
  • Tying off a fallen climber
  • Escape a fallen climber belay
Questions?

title: Safety Evaluation and Joshua Tree Trip
description:
The SCMA Safety Committee will be administering the next Safety Evaluation for prospective new members.

Take part in our half-day safety evaluation to demonstrate your proficiency in some basic climbing skills:

  • Tying the basic climbing knots
  • Rappelling
  • Ascending a rope over an overhang using friction knots
  • Setting multi-directional gear anchors
  • Tying off a fallen climber
  • Escape a fallen climber belay
Questions?

Sheep Pass Group site #3, Friday and Saturday nights
address: 64329-64401 Park Boulevard, Joshua Tree National Park, Joshua Tree, CA 92252, USA

title: Idyllwild Climbers Festival
description:
The Idyllwild Climbers Alliance hosts the  Fifth Annual Climbers Festival in Idyllwild on Sunday May 17.

Coffee and pastries 8-9am, Idyllwild Town Hall.  After breakfast, volunteers will work on trails to the climbing spots.   Barbeque, raffle, silent auction in evening.

Sponsors: the Alliance, Access Fund, Southwest Section of the American Alpine Club. 

RSVP to jlucke@cmc.edu.  Not an SCMA trip.

More details on the SCMA  web site here under Climber News   https://www.rockclimbing.org/index.php/cliff-notes/entry/idyllwild-climbers-festival
address: 25925 Cedar Street, Idyllwild, CA 92549, USA

title: Bart Dome [S1]
description:
Climbing at Bart Dome, Domeland Wilderness, Southern Sierra Nevada, CA

Bart Dome is one of the premier granite in Southern Sierra with single to 3-pitch routes rated from 5.8 to 5.10 trad/bolted climbs. The dome is located about 7 miles from the trailhead so we will backpack in and stay overnight in wilderness for 2 nights.

We will meet at the Manter Meadow Trailhead around 1PM on Friday, 6/5 and hike in together. Although there is Manter Creek that runs parellel along the trail, be prepare to bring in water as a backup since the stream may not have sufficient water due to drought.

Please subscribe to this event if you're interested in attending this trip. I will update with more info in the comment section of this trip as we get closer to the trip weekend.

Driving Direction: Take 5N to 14N. Turn left onto 178W about 10 miles after Red Rock Canyon State Park. At Weldon, turn right onto Sierra Way which becomes Mountain Hwy 99 after Kernville. 19.6 miles after Kernville, turn right onto Sherman Pass Rd(22S05). After 6 miles turn right onto Cherry Hill Rd(22S12). After 11.6 miles turn left at the north intersection of Big Meadow Loop Rd(23S07) and look for Manter Meadow Trailhead (34E14).

To Bart Dome from trailhead: hike east about 3 miles to Manter Meadow. Hike north up Manter Meadow for a few miles until the trail splits; left (34E08)to Woodpecker Meadow and right (34E10) into Tibbets Creek and Rockhouse Basin. Soon you can see Bart Dome down and to the right.

GPS coordinates: 35.887229, -118.332758
address: Sequoia National Forest, Forest Route 23S07, California, USA

title: RCSC #1
description:
Trip Leaders: Steve Sauter and Mike Sauter

Parking for Stoney Point is along a busy street, Topanga Canyon Boulevard. The class will be located on the north end of the rock for most of the day. There is no food, water, bathrooms or other services, so bring what you need.

RMs and AMs come on out and volunteer. The success of the class depends on you,

This will be the first class for the 2016 Rock Climbing Safety Course. Student will be tested on knots and belaying and will be learning rappelling.

SCMA Members – Interested in volunteering at the class? Great! Contact suzanne_dwyer@hotmail.com for additional information.

description:
SCMA Members – Interested in volunteering at the class? Great! You won’t want to miss this one. RM’s we especially need you at this class.

Post-class on Saturday night we will be having a potluck celebrating this year, the 10th year of the Sauters heading up the class. Don’t miss this celebration and the chance to congratulate and thank the Sauters for a decade of service to the club. Additional climbing just for fun on Sunday.

Camping is available Friday and Saturday nights for students and SCMA teaching volunteers. Contact suzanne_dwyer@hotmail.com for additional volunteer and camping information.

title: Big Bear/Holcomb Valley [G]
description:
Climbing in Big Bear area
Leaders: Steve & Mike Sauter
Camping in campgrounds and on BLM land at the crag.

Holcomb Valley Pinnacles is a great sport climbing area with a lot of well bolted routes from 5.4 to 5.11b in the cool, clean San Bernardino Mountains. If you are familiar with the area you can meet us in the lower parking lot or around the crags to sign the route sheet. If you want to carpool in or power up for the day, you can meet us at the Lumber Jack Café by 8:30 for breakfast. You are all welcome back to our cabin for a potluck Bar-B-Que and a shower (bring your own towel). There is plenty of floor space & parking if you want to or, have to stay over. The climbing area is in BLM land and there is plenty of spots to pitch a tent, camper or bivy for the night. Any questions text/call Steve 626-533-6343
address: Holcomb Pinnacles Camp Road, San Bernardino National Forest, Big Bear, CA 92314, USA
venue: Holcomb Valley near Big Bear Lake, CA

title: Family Weekend at Joshua Tree [G]
description:
Joshua Tree Family Weekend
Camp Fri, Sat nights at Indian Cove Sites G6 and G7. Site G6 is available for camping Sun night.
Leader: Virgil Shields/Mike Sauter

Join us once again for a fun, family friendly weekend of climbing, camping and community with the SCMA Family Weekend.

This trip is open to the families of SCMA members. It is a great time to share your love for climbing and the outdoors with your favorite people. Kids, brothers, sisters, mom’s and dad’s are all welcome.
The more the merrier. We have two group sites in Indian Cove to gather together.

The club has a large collection of climbing shoes of all sizes, and harnesses for your troop. Bring your own helmets.

We will have top ropes established for the group on Saturday and Sunday.

Don’t forget the firewood, food and the smores!

If you have any questions please send me an email.

Mike Sauter msauter@mac.com
address: 68700-69098 Indian Cove Rd N, Twentynine Palms, CA 92277, USA
venue: Indian Cove Group Campsites, Joshua Tree

title: SCMA Sponsors Caltech Alpine Club Talk
description:
Beckman Institute Auditorium, 7:00 PM

Join in on the many adventures of climber and artist Kelvin Nguyen as he shares his experiences through his visual journal; traveling from local climbing destinations to his recent summit of Alpamayo in Peru.

A professional designer and illustrator, Kelvin uses his artistic skills to convey his experience of climbing and capture his outings in a unique and personal way. Kelvin’s work includes his interpretations of trad-climbing, ice climbing, mountaineering, bouldering, camping, traveling, mountain culture, beautiful alpine scenery and more. The unique nature of this presentation is sure to be a standout in the series.

Alpine Club Talks, held in the Beckman Institute Auditorium on the Caltech campus in Pasadena, are free and open to the public. Free parking is available after 6:00 PM. The talk will be followed by a reception with refreshments.

title: SCMA Anchor Building Clinic with Thom Wolfsen
description:
Have you ever looked at an anchor and wondered: how equalized is this thing? Does it really matter? Can it even be achieved? Is the angle between pieces critical (maybe not as much as you think)? Is the direction of pull really that important?

If you’re looking to improve your anchor building skills or just need a refresher, come on out and join the fun in J-Tree with Thom Wolfsen as he discusses the finer points of constructing load distribution systems. This day-long clinic will combine discussion with plenty of hands-on practice in building strong, safe anchors for toprope, single-pitch and multi-pitch climbing. Topics covered will include: static vs. dynamic load distribution, building anchors in series, dynamic elongation, how single-point failure can compromise multi-point anchors and much more. You’ll learn and practice the tips, tricks and techniques that will enable you to have confidence in your anchors wherever you may build them, while challenging the skills you already possess.

Note: There is no charge for the clinic but we can only accommodate 12 people, so contact Thom at VI511A4@hotmail.com to sign-up.

Note: There is no charge for the clinic but we can only accommodate 12 people, so contact Thom atÂÂ VI511A4@hotmail.comÂÂ to sign-up.

When: Sunday, January 15th, 2017

Where: Real Hidden Valley, Joshua Tree National Park; South end of Sports Challenge Rock.

Time: 8:00 a.m. until 4:00 p.m. (meet at the parking lot area)
address: Unnamed Road, Twentynine Palms, CA 92277, USA

title: Mount Shasta (S2)
description:
Mt. Shasta climb via Avalanche Gulch, May 7-13, 2017

Join us on our inaugural mountaineering trip to Mt. Shasta! Â We’ve planned a slower paced ascent of Mt. Shasta via Avalanche Gulch that includes instruction and practice in the basics of mountaineering for those that need it. Â Â We’ll re view basic crampon and ice axe use, self-arrest, snow anchors and basic crevasse rescue.Â While many climbers storm the mountain doing 2 or 3-day ascents, our slower pace will enable us to practice our mountaineering skills and allows us extra time to acclimatize before our summit attempt while hanging out with our fellow club members enjoying the beauty of Mt. Shasta’s wilderness.

No previous mountaineering experience is required for this trip but you should be in good physical condition and have previous backpacking experience (especially winter). The itinerary is flexible depending on the final group make-up and we can make adjustments depending on the skill set and desires of the group.

For details about the trip, check out the Mountaineering “Trip Planning” section of the forum.

Group size: limited to 8 people. Trip rating: S2

Trip leader: Thom Wolfsen

Co-leader: Â Alexander SmirnoffÂ

title: Shuteye Ridge [G]
description:
Shuteye Ridge is an area riddled with granite and lush moss covered forest. It is located in the Western Sierras South of Yosemite and East of Bass Lake. There are no official campgrounds, bathrooms, or water. It is undeveloped remote camping and you must bring your own supplies. Climbing areas range from walking distance to miles of approach and offer everything from runout slab to vertical sport on runnels.

Leader: Â Randy Worth Â 

There will be two groups leaving Friday. One group going in the morning and my group leaving in the evening after work. This year will be chilly with more snow than usual so be prepared for mountain weather. Vehicles must be AWD with chains at a minimum. There will be multiple 4wheel drive trucks going to fit anyone in need of a ride.

We will be camping at Big Sleep Dome climbing area which is considered Brown’s Meadow. Anyone interested in coming must email me, Randy Worth, to discuss vehicle/rides.

Here is my trip report from last year on mountain project:
http://www.supertopo.com/climbers-forum/2820646/Shuteye-Ridge-Conditions-Report

Here are the directions that Trish Stoops has created:
The Road names in this area vary depending on which map you use. Â Do not use Googlemaps. Â I know you all love google but the names they give don’t match what’s actually out there. Â Look at mapquest and you’ll see the correct street names. PLEASE NOTE THAT I HAVE NOT FOUND ANY GPS SYSTEM THAT CORRECTLY SHOWS THE DIRT ROADS THAT YOU ENCOUNTER TOWARDS THE END, SO FROM THAT POINT, TURN OFF YOUR GPS, READ THE DIRECTIONS, AND CHECK OFF THE MILEAGE LISTED BELOW Â ;o)
Â 
From Fresno take Hwy 41 north to North Fork Road, turn right (may also be called Road 200). Travel east to North Fork. Â When you get close to North Fork you’ll pass Manzinita road on the left. Keep straight and the road you’re on will become Mammoth Road, which intersects with Malum Road (Malum Road leads to Bass Lake – so pass it and head straight going up the hill) Â  From that intersection, keep going on Mammoth Road for 22 miles. Â Its all paved. Â You may see some road signs that say “Minarets Road” but mostly its called Mammoth Road and later on it will be called Mammoth Pool Road and eventually you’ll see a few signs designating it as “81.”
Â 
Towards the beginning of those 22 miles you will come to a Y-intersection. Â Take the left fork of the Y. Â Road 225 goes right, Mammoth Pool Road is to the left. Â KEEP LEFT. Â Along the way you’ll pass two fire stations, and Powerhouse Road and you’ll go through a large section of burned forest. Â At the 22 mile mark you’ll see ROCK CREEK CAMPGROUND on the right. WE ARE NOT STAYING AT ROCK CREEK CAMPGROUND, ITS JUST A LANDMARK!
Â 
The location of Rock Creek Campground that is shown on Googlemaps and Mapquest seems to not match up with what is really out there, so PLEASE, don’t blindly follow your GPS from this point. Â Many people end up lost by doing so.
Â 
Drive another 3/4 mile past Rock Creek Campground and you’ll see a dirt road that Y’s off to the left with a sign that says “Brown’s Meadow and Whiskey Falls” Â Take that dirt road for 7.3 miles (The guidebook refers to this as Road 7S02 – don’t search for it on a map using that name – you won’t find it).Â 
Â 
Take the dirt road, 7S02, for 7.3 miles. Â Turn HARD right onto 7S02M Â (there is a tiny marker that actually says 7S02M). Â From there its another ½ mile of bumpy road to our camp.
Â 
Note: you’ll pass many 7S02 offshoots but they will NOT appear in Alphabetical order, so don’t be thrown off by that, just drive the 7.3 miles and you’ll be fine Â :O)
Â 
The road opens onto a beautiful flat slab below Big Sleep Dome. Â This is CAMP. Â There are several fire pits / camp spots along the slab, and there will likely be other groups there.
address: Rd 7S02, NE of the town of North Fork, CA (correct road does not show on this map).

title: Idyllwild Climber's Festival
description:
On Sunday, June 4, 2017 the Idyllwild Climbers Alliance will host its Seventh Annual Climbers Festival. Â  For the second consecutive year, focus will be on the Black Mountain area, which will improve access to camping and bouldering, as well as removing any trash and debris within the area. Also, continue to maintain the three main climber’s trails, Lunch Rock, the North Face of Tahquitz, and Suicide Rock. Â 
Volunteers will meet at Idyllwild's Town Hall to enjoy coffee and pastries before heading out to the trails! Following a day of hard work, the alliance will have lunch in addition to a chance to win a raffle and bid on awesome gear.
Don’t miss out on keeping a classic climbing area accessible!

Event details below.
When: Sunday, June 4th, 2017 @ 8:00 am – 1:00 pm
Where: 25925 Cedar St. Idyllwild, CA 92549
What: Idyllwild’s Climbers Festival
Camping RSVP: Email Merritt King - papercolor@gmail.com
Clean-up/Festival RSVP: Eventbrite:
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/idyllwild-climbers-festival-tickets-33084513671 Â Â 

Not an SCMA trip.

title: Challenged Climbing Opportunity [G]
description:
Challenged Climbing Opportunity
We will assist and demonstrate skills with a group of hearing-challenged climbers; some are learning to climb and some are experienced. They are over 18 years old.
No Braille climbers this time. We're still going to focus on trying to help an under-served part of the community. For this SCMA trip a group of deaf and American Sign language users, as will as SCMA climbers will come out and have an opportunity to experience a weekend of outdoor climbing.

Come out as a volunteer for support and to climb.. Group Campsite 5 (Hodgepodge Rock). ÂÂ Camping Friday and Saturday nights.Â Â 

See details in blog by Mark Irving on the SCMA web site.

title: Reel Rock 11 at Chapman University
description:
The Southern California Mountaineering Associating (SCMA) and the Chapman University Outdoors Club partner to present Reel Rock 11 on the Chapman University Campus in Orange, CA

title: Red Rocks [G] Thanksgiving
description:
BLM Campground - Group Site B

Camping five nights -- Wed, Thu, Fri, Sat, Sun

Leaders: LeRoy Russ/Fred Batliner

The Red Rock Canyon Campground is located two miles east of the Red Rocks Visitor Center on West Charleston Boulevard (State Route 159.)

Thanksgiving Dinner and

Saturday Leftovers/Potluck


Thanksgiving Dinner

Thursday November 23rd @ 7:00 pm--you are welcome to come any time after 6:00 pm.

Food--We are providing turkey, a vegan “roast,” gravy, stuffing, cranberry sauce, mashed potatoes, sweet potatoes, yellow turnips, a relish dish, apple and pumpkin pies, cake and ice cream. For the gravy, pies, cake and ice cream we are providing both vegan and non-vegan versions, and the remainder of the side dishes are vegan. We’ll have soft drinks, wine, coffee and tea (for beer, bring your own). It’s not necessary to bring anything but an appetite. However, if the items listed above would leave you missing a favorite Thanksgiving dish, feel free to bring it.

Leftovers/Potluck

Saturday November 25th @ 7:00 pm--you are welcome to come any time after 6:00 pm.

This dinner will be whatever is left over from the Thanksgiving dinner, plus whatever you choose to bring.

Directions to 10194 Birch Bluff

Exit the campground; turn right on Hwy 159, which becomes Charleston Blvd. Turn left on Indigo (a little past Town Center Drive), after the Stop sign cross Park Run and enter the gate directly ahead (gate code is 2683), turn left on Juniper Creek (just inside gate), right on Sumac Springs, right on Birch Bluff. Look for 10194 on your left. Park in our driveway or in the visitor parking down the street on the right (two areas). If no visitor parking is available, go back out and park on the street.

Sponsors—LeRoy--leruss@earthlink.net/323 449-0283, Margo--margopkr@gmail.com/323 449-0249

Please tell us if you are planning to come and whether you and family members or friends coming with you are vegan or non-vegan, so that we know how much food is needed. Let LeRoy know by email, text or phone/voicemail.
address: Moenkopi Road, Las Vegas, NV, USA

title: Dirtbag: The Legend of Fred Beckey
description:
The Southern California Mountaineering Association (SCMA), The Keck Climbing Club, and Stronghold Climbing Gym are excited to host a screening of Dirtbag: The Legend of Fred Beckey on March 8, 2018, 7:30 PM.

Fred Beckey is the original American “Dirtbag” climber whose name has evoked mystery, adulation and vitriol since the 1940s. Beckey’s stubborn, singular quest to conquer peaks meant a solitary life on the road, where he left a long trail of scorned climbing partners and lost lovers in his wake.

Fred Beckey passed away peacefully on October 30, 2017. Fred was a true American icon. His legacy is profound, and he has inspired countless people to explore this amazing planet.

The groundbreaking life story of this rebel athlete, who inspired generations with his monumental first ascents, eloquent books and the lifestyle he fearlessly pioneered, is told for the first time in this exclusive documentary film. There is only one Fred Beckey. His legacy in the mountains will live on forever.

Dirtbag: The Legend of Fred Beckey played more than 25 film festivals in 2017, winning 13 awards including five Grand Prizes and two Audience Awards. Â 

Tickets: tickets may be purchased in advance for $15.00 at https://www.eventbrite.com/e/dirtbag-the-legend-of-fred-beckey-tickets-42622268352

DIRTBAG: THE LEGEND OF FRED BECKEY
March 8, 2018, 7:30-9:00 pm
Broad/CIRM Center, Keck School of Medicine
1st Floor Conference Room
1425 San Pablo Street, Los Angeles, CA 90033

Parking is available in the lot adjacent to the Broad/CIRM Center (enter from Eastlake Ave) or on streetsides Eastlake Ave, Norfolk St, Biggy St, or Alcazar St.

For more information about the film, see the website: Â 
http://dirtbagmovie.com/index.html
address: 1425 San Pablo St, Los Angeles, CA 90033, USA
venue: Broad/CIRM Center, Keck School of Medicine

title: RCSC #5
description:
Trip Leaders: Steve & Mike Sauter, Suzanne Steiner

Student/Volunteer potluck Sat after class - G8

We have some camping Saturday night for volunteers and students that want to stay over, however unfortunately there will be no parking available in the campsite as we only have one very small group site with a handful of parking spaces and those spots are reserved for the folks bringing, setting up and taking down the mountain of class gear. Overnight parking is available for a small fee at the Indian Cove Market. Park in day use parking (Good until 10:00 PM) and if you plan to stay overnight you can drop you stuff off at the campsite, move your car to the market, and someone will shuttle you back to the site.

As this is a RCSC class, guests are not permitted.

venue: Indian Cove Group Campsites, Joshua Tree

title: Memorial Hike in Memory of R.J. Secor
description:
Join us on a hike Sunday, April 15, 2018 to Henniger Flats, Angeles NF as a celebration of our friend R. J. Secor’s life (1956-2017). This moderate local climb from the mouth of Eaton CanyonÂ up the Mt. Wilson Toll Road was R J.’s favorite local conditining hike. Henniger Flats has picnic tables, restrooms, and a nature center.Â  We plan to haveÂ our celebration when we get to the Flats, so bring your R.J. stories, memories,and food and drink to share.

Expect a day's total of about 5.35 miles round trip with 1,300’ of gain.Â  We’ll leave from the Pinecrest trailhead in Altadena (2200 block) at 8:00 am.Â  Parking is limited,so plan to carpool if you can. Some may want to park at the Eaton Canyon Nature Center and carpool from there Kids and dogs are welcome.

Please email contact info to leaders:ÂÂ ÂÂ Dan Richter (dan@danrichter.com), Asher Waxman
address: 2260 Pinecrest Dr, Altadena, CA 91001, USA

title: Tamarack Lake and Saber Ridge, Sierra Nevada
description:
This trip will be a backcountry trip to Tamarack Lake / Saber Ridge in the High Sierras. The 15 mile approach to Tamarack Lake is a full day’s hike. Once at Tamarack Lake, there are multiple long alpine climbs ranging from 5.7 to 5.10 and higher.ÂÂ  We will spend one day hiking in, 2 days climbing, then hike out the last day.Â  Because of the early summer season and the high altitude of Tamarack Lake (9000 ft), members must be experienced in snow travel. Due to the long approach and seriousness of the climbing in the alpine environment, any member who wishes to participate in this trip needs to contact the trip leader via email (anoukerni82@gmail.com) to discuss his/her experience level.Â  Register on the SCMA website calendar, and watch for updated comments posted by the trip leader.
Leader: Anouk Erni

title: Ice Climbing at Ouray, Colorado [G]
description:
Ice Climbing at Ouray, Colorado.
Leaders: Anouk Erni, Steve Cole
Ouray is a great place to learn to ice climb or to enhance your skills to the next level. There is top rope ice and lead ice right at the edge of town, but also backcountry ice and backcountry skiing nearby.ÂÂ There is no reserved campsite or accommodation for this trip. In the past, members have either gotten their own accommodations via airbnb or vrbo, gotten a campsite near town, or shared with others. If you are interested in attending, please register on the SCMA site and indicate:
1) what level ice climber you are (i.g. novice, TR only, lead up to..., etc)
2) what are the dates you intend to be there
3) will you be acquiring your own accommodations or are you interested in sharing a larger accommodation with others
4) if you are bringing a partner or will be looking to partner with someone from the group.
Â  Options to get to Ouray: drive fly (closest airports are Grand Junction, Denver, and Montrose)Â Â 
Â  Please abide by SCMA trip guest rules as they apply for this trip.
Â  Please email Anouk, trip co-leader, atÂ anoukerni82@gmail.comÂÂ with any questions about the trip. There is also some communication going on about the trip on Facebook if you are looking for partners or want to find out more.

title: Echo Cliffs Stewardship, April 13, 14, 19, 20
description:
• Saturday, April 13th & Sunday, April 14th
  • Friday, April 19th & Saturday, April 20th

Join us for one or more days over the two weekends to support the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area as it recovers, and to help lay the groundwork for future partnerships to maintain Echo Cliffs.Â  Projects will include access clearing, downed tree removal, and erosion mitigation/prevention work.Â  Plan to bring your own lunch, wear work boots or approach shoes, bring work gloves, sun protection, and plenty of water.

Access Fund/ SCMA co-organized Adapt-A-Craig Event.Â April 13 & 14 is sponsored by Sender One and April 19 & 20 is sponsored by Stronghold.Â  Â Â 

Not a SCMA Club trip.

title: Squamish, (15th Annual) British Columbia 2019 [G]
description:
Squamish, (15th Annual) British Columbia 2019

SCMA members (Regular, Associate, Applicant, Student, etc.) are invited to join LeRoy Russ for climbing in Squamish, B.C. Approximately Jul 1st thru August 31th (I may extend stay into Sept). Squamish is on Howe Sound about 45 minutes from Vancouver and 45 minutes from Whistler, The Chief is granite of Yosemite size and quality with multi-pitch climbing galore. And many sport climbing areas, such as Smoke Bluffs Murrin Park, etc. All within walking distance of the townhouse, as are restaurants, shopping and Starbucks! Besides the Chief itself, which offers big walls as well as an apron with moderate friction and small-hold climbing, there are also several other large formations within easy driving/walking distance. Besides climbing there is kayaking, windsurfing, kite sailing, hiking and much more to do. Area is suitable for non-climbers and kids.Accommodations— Condo sleeps 8 or so, and is located one block off the main street, on the water and near the rock. The town has four climbing shops—this is in a town smaller than Mammoth! —And several ethnic restaurants. You can get there by plane, train, ferry, bus or car. Ride service from Vancouver, www.poparide.com

A $40 accommodation fee to cover, utilities, group staples, cleaning, etc. per person per stay (kids are free). No it’s not per night. Dinners are usually group affairs with all contributing. Wi-Fi is available in the condo. Not necessary to buy a guidebook, unless you are a collector.

The Squamish Climbing Festival takes place July with clinics, slideshows, vendor exhibits, raffles, etc.

Contact LeRoy to arrange dates @H- 323-227-4973, Cell-323-449-0283

Passports required, not by me, but by Canadian Customs.

Contact me for driving info from Los Angeles or Vancouver.
address: British Columbia, Canada

title: Show:   Alpine Climbing in the High Sierra
description:
Justin Barham, SCMA member,Â  ALPINE CLIMBING IN THE HIGH SIERRA, Wednesday 7:30 pm Caltech Campus, Pasadena.Â Â 
Show features alpine rock climbs on easily accessible and amazing climbs in the High Sierra.Â  Featured are 5th class routes on Lone Pine Peak, Humphries, Whitney, Conness, Bear Creel Spire, Cathedral Peak and more.
The SCMA along with the Caltech Alpine Club present this show at the Beckman Institute Auditorium the Caltech Campus at 1200 East California Boulevard, Pasadena, California.
Parking is free and available on Wilson just south of Del Mar or in the structure off Wilson after 6:00pm
Free pizza and beer after the show.

title: Big Rock "Adopt a Crag" - Sunday, March 8
description:
This event is an Access Fund / SCMA “Adopt-a-Crag” project. The Access Fund Conservation Team will be there on Sunday, March 8th to partner and help us to continue our work at Big Rock.


Signup here on the Trip Calendar. We have reserved a group campsite at the Lake Perris for Saturday night (3/7) so you can climb Saturday, camp Saturday night, and help out with the service project on Sunday. Or just come on out Sunday ready to work.


Group campsite #1 in the Bernasconi Campground.
Overnight parking pass provided for the first 10 people to sign up.


Trip leader: Steve Sauter

description:
Since our regular club events had to be canceled, we are hoping that can join us for a virtual club get-together. We would love to say hello to our new club members and RCSC students, and hear stories about one of your most memorable climbing / mountain trips.Â 
The Board would also like to share perspectives from the Access Fund and other LCOs about what the new normal for the climbing community may look like once COVID stay at home order are starting to get relaxed.Â

title: Bear Creek Spire [S1]
description:
This trip is contingent on SCMA Board opening up trips again after COVID19 cancellations.
Saturday we’ll enjoy a hike in through the ridiculously pretty Little Lakes Valley, camping at Dade Lake. Sunday we’ll rise and climb routes such the Sierra uber-classic Northeast Ridge (5.3), or the more challenging North Arete (5.8).
This is a backcountry trip with very limited space. Please email interest and/or questions to Justin at justin.barham@me.com.
Leaders: Justin Barham and Dave German
venue: Bear Creek Spire, Rock Creek area

title: Joshua Tree [G]
description:
Camping Fri and Sat nights at Joshua Tree, Indian Cove Group site #6Â 
Trip leader: Juan Carlos Marvizon
A mandatory RSVP, no less than 72 hours prior to a club trip, is required for the remainder of 2020. With your reservation, please submit a valid email address so that we may send the revised club release for e-signature.The goal is to reduce paperwork being physically handled by the trip leader and the club participants.

Trip leaders will not enforce guidelines for wearing masks, social distancing or hand washing/sanitizing. Personal protective equipment, such as masks and hand sanitizer, will not be provided to trip participants by trip leaders. Before registering for a trip, participants should decide if these parameters are acceptable to them. It should be clearly understood that any safeguards or precautions against the transmission of COVID-19 are outside the responsibility of the trip leader and the SCMA. It is the sole responsibility of trip participants to behave in a manner that minimizes transmission by wearing a mask, social distancing and washing hands when appropriate.
address: Joshua Tree National Park, 68700-69098 Indian Cove Road North, Twentynine Palms, CA 92277, USA
venue: Indian Cove Group Campground, Joshua Tree

title: Caltech Alpine Club virtual film festival event, March 10 evening.
description:
The Caltech Alpine Club is excited to announce that this year, it will be hosting the Banff Mountain Film Festival World Tour virtually!
Banff Centre put together four programs (2 hours each, made of 3-9 films) for tour hosts, and Caltech has chosen to watch the Amber program during the event, which will be held on March 10th from 7-9:30pm. The plan is that everyone attending this event will rent the Amber program individually and watch it concurrently over Zoom. There will be an intermission in the middle, during which there will be a raffle, photo contest with prizes, and slideshow (SCMA is featured).
Rent the Amber movie program here ($15 per ticket - (**note you have 3 days once you start watching the program**)
https://filmfest.banffcentre.ca/?campaign=WT-156496
Join the Zoom meeting
Zoom meeting link for Virtual 45th Banff Mountain Film Festival WT
Time: Mar 10, 2021 07:00 PM Pacific Time
Link: https://caltech.zoom.us/j/87357918194...
Meeting ID: 873 5791 8194
Passcode: banff2021

title: Courtright Reservoir [G]
description:
Courtright Reservoir
Camping Friday night July 2nd and Saturday night July 3rd, 2021
Trapper Springs Campground
Reserved 4 sites (limit 3 vehicles, 6 occupants per site)
Trip leader will manage campsite occupancy and vehicles. Must reserve with the trip leader to camp at SCMA campsite before attending.
Note: We can accommodate 24 campers not 24 vehicles. CARPOOL!

This trip in the past has had a large attendance; our reserve campsites fill quickly. Contact trip leader and reserve as soon as you can. If SCMA sites are filled we suggest purchasing a campsite on your own (recreation.pge.com). Contact trip leader for other alternatives.

Trip Leader: John Gonzales
Email: scmajohnxrcs@gmail.com

Note: The official Courtright trip will start July 1st and run through July 5th. Club campsites are July 2nd and July 3rd. Obviously members need to purchase campsites on their own to make this trip a 5 day outing.

Those that have, offer the extra occupancy to SCMA members. If you are one of the lucky participants it’s customary to contribute to the cost of the site with the member that purchases it, that includes parking fees if any.

If you would like to attend this trip and need help, contact the trip leader (scmajohnxrcs@gmail.com) for direction, camping and any pertinent info about this trip.Â 

To book a campsite, go online to PG&E's recreation site at recreation.pge.com
Enlarge map and click on Trapper Springs Campground. Continue and you will need to register with address, phone etc. See availability and to book.Â 
Also the camp host will sell sites there at the campground for first come first serve basis.


Trip leaders will not enforce guidelines for wearing masks, social distancing or hand washing/sanitizing. title: Moab Camping and Climbing.[G]
description:
Camping:Â  Moab Gold Bar Campground Group Site DÂ 
Leader: Jessica Ary
Gold Bar Campground is located along the Colorado River, 20 minutes from Moab. There's easy access to climbing along Potash Road and it's only 45 minutes from Castle Valley. Indian Creek can also be done as a nice day trip. Moab also offers mountain biking, hiking, and several nearby National Parks. It's a perfect destination for both climbers and non-climbers alike.

description:

title: Red Rocks [G]
description:
BLM Campground Group Site : "Roadrunner"ÂÂÂ 
Camping three nights : Fri, Sat, Sun
Leaders: LeRoy Russ/Fred Batliner

The Red Rock Canyon Campground is located two miles east of the Red Rocks Visitor Center on West Charleston Boulevard (State Route 159.)

Trip leaders will not enforce guidelines for wearing masks, social distancing or hand washing/sanitizing. Personal protective equipment, such as masks and hand sanitizer, will not be provided to trip participants by trip leaders. Before registering for a trip, participants should decide if these parameters are acceptable to them. It should be clearly understood that any safeguards or precautions against the transmission of COVID-19 are outside the responsibility of the trip leader and the SCMA. It is the sole responsibility of trip participants to behave in a manner that minimizes transmission by wearing a mask, social distancing and washing hands when appropriate.

If you haven't already, please sign the updated Covid-19 digital waiver prior to attending a club trip.
If you're bringing a guest, please also make sure he/she signs this digital waiver prior to the trip.ÂÂÂ 
The digital waiver is at :
https://waiver.smartwaiver.com/v/scma/

title: Courtright Reservoir (G)
description:
Courtright Reservoir Trapper Springs Campground
Reserved 4 sites. Will add more campsites if needed (each site limits 3 vehicles and 6 occupants).
Trip leaders will manage campsite occupancy and vehicles. Must reserve with the trip leader to camp in an SCMA campsite before attending. Carpool!
This trip in the past has had a large attendance, our reserved campsites fill quickly, so contact trip
leader as soon as you can.
Trip Leader: John Gonzales
Email: scmajohnxrcs@gmail.com
This trip was scheduled well in advance. The dates may change due to a late opening of Trapper
Springs campground; if you can’t make the new dates let the trip leader know.
Note: The trip leaders usually arrive 2 or 3 days early and stay a day or so after the official trip.

title: North Cascades National Park, WA
description:
Location: North Cascades National Park / Washington Pass, WA
Campground: Colonial Creek North Campground
Site: 36 : (start on 7/2) ;ÂÂÂ  sites 7, 22, 156ÂÂÂ  : (start on 7/3)
Overview
As one of the best campgrounds in North Cascades National Park and accessed via the seasonal North Cascades Scenic Highway 20, Colonial Creek Campground is one of the most popular bases to explore this rugged region of Washington.
Campground amenities
Drinking water, flush toilets, dump station, amphitheater, boat ramp, food storage lockers.
Firewood is available for sales from the camp host in the North loop, or can be purchased in Marblemount, WA.
Activities
Outdoor recreation activities include hiking, boating, canoeing, kayaking, boat-in camping, fishing, picnicking, mountain biking and hiking. There’s also nice wildlife viewing and photo opportunities. You’ll see a variety of bird species, deer and also an occasional bear.
Climbing Areas
Washington Pass – trad / alpine climbing
The Washington Pass area includes some spectacular and easily accessible alpine granite climbs, ranging in difficulty from the 5.4-rated South Arete of South Early Winter and to hard 5.12 climbs such as the Thin Red Line on Liberty Bell and the Tiger on M&M Wall. The area also has classic aid routes such as Liberty Crack on Liberty Bell.
https://www.mountainproject.com/area/105792192/washington-pass
Mazama – sport climbing
https://www.mountainproject.com/area/106112166/mazama
Boat-in Camping
There are 3 boat-in campsites within 3 miles from Colonial Creek campground. If you’d like to do an overnight excursion, please obtain a backcountry permit. Ross Lake Resort has equipment rental.
https://www.nps.gov/noca/planyourvisit/boat-in-camping.htm
https://www.rosslakeresort.com/equipment-rentals
Dates: 7/2/2022 - 7/10/2022
Trip Leader: Ming Hsieh
